Story:
I sat in the living room, my hands trembling as I held the ceremonial script my parents had given me. They looked at me with pride, expecting me to lead the family ceremony tonight, just as my older siblings had done before me. This was important to them—an unbroken tradition, a symbol of our family’s unity and respect for our heritage. I wanted to make them proud, to show I valued what mattered to them.

But my phone buzzed again. It was my best friend, Mia. Her last message was short and cold, a clear sign she was upset. She’d misunderstood my earlier text, thinking I was annoyed with her, and now she was hurt. I knew I needed to call her right away, to explain and fix things before the misunderstanding grew. That’s what friends do—we talk things out, honestly and quickly.

I stared at the phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family’s expectant eyes, the script in my lap, and Mia’s hurt in my pocket. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be both the child my parents needed and the friend Mia deserved, all at the same time.
